message: Today I want you to help with a specific strand of Research for the Edinburgh City Council’s Public art research Project.
You will take me on a curated experience involving three works of art; art that is transformative, contentious, and new.
Are you ready to get started?
Please take me to a public work of art that is transformative...
Ok, let me know when we get there.
What are we looking at? Take a pic and tell me it’s name.
Alright, I am gonna ask some deep questions now.
Who or what is this transformative for and why?

It is meant to represent people in the city but it was created by a non local artist. I think it is more that it’s meant to be a generic image of the councils focus on the city but it lacks the sense of place a local artist could bring.
Could you please expand on the quality, taste, and appropriateness of this work of art?
Focus on any or all points and take a pic if it helps.
The art work is too simplistic for me. I’d like to have seen something more suitable to the city. This statue has been reused in other cities so it’s not even unique.
Could you expand on the context about this work of art?
Would you like to say anything else about this work of art or any issue related?
Please take me to a public work of art that is contentious...
Ok, let me know when we get there.
,"\"What are we looking at? Take a pic and tell me it’s name.\
What makes this work of art contentious? And for whom?
The cost, for those paying (the public)

This is an amazing piece of art and architecture. Scotland is so lucky to have this but the talk was all about the money. It’s European design which is also has Scottish references means it is truly unique and politically the Scottish Parliament is recognised internationally

This is an amazing piece of art and architecture. Scotland is so lucky to have this but the talk was all about the money. It’s European design which is also has Scottish references means it is truly unique and politically the Scottish Parliament is recognised internationally

This is an amazing piece of art and architecture. Scotland is so lucky to have this but the talk was all about the money. It’s European design which is also has Scottish references means it is truly unique and politically the Scottish Parliament is recognised internationally
Our research shows contention raises issues of inclusivity and exclusivity... Does this work of art have issues with inclusivity and exclusivity?
Because it is for an entire nation
Similarly contentious works of art have elements of trust and risk. Can you expand on either or both?
Because any new work that represents an entity has these elements. It’s part of the territory and so normal.
Would you like to say anything more about this work of art or any issue related?
Could you please take me to a public space that could use a new work of art or somewhere where a public work of art could be replaced?
Ok, let me know when we get there.
Where are we? Take a pic too
Black ford Hill looking towards Arthur’s seat
Why have you chosen this place?
Add a pic if it helps...

Edinburgh is built on seven hills. They are iconic viewpoints in the city loved by citizens, tourists and visitors. Walkers and runners use them every day. Biodiversity is huge with many species living on them. They represent the geological history of Edinburgh which is volcanic. There is an opportunity here to create contemporary art works to celebrate their different characters
How does this disrupt the space? And who will be affected and why?

It would be quite disruptive in terms of heritage which has supporters for not adding contemporary work and those who would like to move Edinburgh, now a cosmopolitanism and international city, into an artistic future. For local people it would be very contentious
Could you list the agencies, parties and individuals that should be involved for placing a work of art here?
Edinburgh Council and various departments, Scottish wildlife trust, Hudtorc Environment Scotland, Scottish Government, Creative Scotland and many others

Our research shows the process for a public art project can lack transparency for interested parties. Given the place and potentiality for a work of art here, can you imagine what a transparent process would be?
Please give me insight by steps or association and order-of groups involved.

Full on public engagement for this project would be essential with co-design included. There would be a number of art groups in the city who would want to be interested as well as professional bodies.
Yes, I would recommend we change our approach to commissioning art to a collective one where participation and design is done as part of the process.
Yes, I would recommend we change our approach to commissioning art to a collective one where participation and design is done as part of the process.
Yes, I would recommend we change our approach to commissioning art to a collective one where participation and design is done as part of the process.
Well, that’s a lot to think about... Are there any other issues that you would like to address in the context of process?
In this place and process, what expertise does the public have to offer?
Their sense of place. They live in the environment but they also want to have a say in how it changes and evolves
Our research indicates particular issues are left out of the conversation when logistics and process take precedent about the use of a public space. Can you reflect on...?
Please explain, add a pic if it helps

There should be fun, enjoyment and pleasure before, during and after the process for a new piece of public art. By engaging all ages and relevant audiences for the work you will create sustainable ownership and appreciation
Would you Like to address a different issue?
Please explain, add a pic if it helps
There should be a consistent element of learning for any commission pitched from kids to older folk.
Would you like to say anything more about any issues related to our current conversation?

In Edinburgh public art is contentious and a difficult path to navigate. Any changes to existing work such as removal, always causes uproar even if there is a good reason. New work has to recognise its place in the city as it was, currently is and will evolve in the future. New buildings bring the worst reactions and contemporary builds tend to fail on the visual front fir this reason. Everyone tries too hard. There should be more flexibility towards the development of Edinburgh as a city but its history and its politics make this challenging. The commissioning process and even the understanding of what is a public work of art, are also challenging.
Thank you for your patience and participation But before you return me, do you have anything you would like to underscore or add to the conversation?
That’s all good. You’ve been a great help towards this research....
Tell me about it and take a pic if it helps...
